item.title: Veeam Backup for Microsoft 365 v6
item.description: After completing my PowerShell script to upgrade Veeam Backup & Replication environments to v10, I wanted to take the next step and automate the full lifecycle process. I’ve had Ansible in my sights for a while to do this as it can natively use PowerShell. Markus Kraus, a Veeam VanGaurd, started work along this same train of thought last year and recently updated the code to support Veeam Backup & Replication v10.

item.title: Automated Upgrade to Veeam v11
item.description: After the release of Veeam Backup & Replication v10 last year, I wrote a PowerShell script to automate the upgrade. It’s as easy as they come as it enabled one-click upgrades of Veeam environments. With the release of v11, I wanted to continue the tradition to enable those with multiple Veeam servers, the easy button for mass upgrades to the latest version of the product. I’m happy to announce the release of an updated version of this script for v11!

item.title: Ansible Update for Veeam v11
item.description: Veeam Backup & Replication v11 officially launched last week! With a new version of the product that is jam-packed with features, it’s no wonder that it’s already passed 15,000 unique downloads! Even before it was released, I was already being asked the question…when will the Veeam Collection for Ansible support v11? The answer is…right now! The collection now fully supports all major components of the Veeam Availablility Suite: Veeam Backup & Replication Veeam Backup Enterprise Manager Veeam ONE To the credit of the Veeam development team, there wasn’t much I had to do on my end for this.

item.title: Quick Ansible Setup
item.description: NOTE: This solution should only be used in non-production environments as a method to get familiar with Ansible. For production use, I recommend installing Ansible on a dedicated Linux server. An automated deployment tool is a must have for any IT environment. In my lab, that’s Ansible. I’ve used Ansible in my lab to automate VM deployment/destruction, adding SSH keys for remote access to my servers, joining/leaving AD domain, and monitoring the newly deployed VMs.

item.title: Veeam Plugin for vCD w/ SSO
item.description: With the release of Veeam Backup & Replication version 10 around the corner, it’s only fitting that we get some added goodness with a new version of the Veeam Plugin for vCloud Director. I’m happy to announce that a new version of the plugin is available today! New features of the plugin include: Single Sign-On (SSO) capability Support for Veeam Backup & Replication version 10 Support for VMware vCloud Director 10 Documentation for deployment & configuration of this plugin can be found here.

item.title: First Look: Veeam Plugin for vCD
item.description: Veeam Backup & Replication version 9.5 released the vCloud Director (vCD) Self Service Portal that leverages Enterprise Manager and allows vCD Tenants to fully administer backups for their vCD workloads. Upon release, Veeam made consumption of this Self Service Portal as easy as possible as it leverages vCD authentication for tenants so they don’t have to manage two sets of credentials. Even so, it was still a separate portal independent of vCD.

item.title: GitLab CI Artifact Expiration
item.description: Note: If you’re unfamiliar with GitLab CI, I highly recommend you try it out on GitLab.com for free. A few months ago, the disk space on my on-prem GitLab instance began to fill up. Fortunately for me, my monitoring reported the issue before it became a major problem. My first thought was, why is this happening? I knew that I had provisioned more than enough space and there should be no reason it was almost full.
